net.xuset.objectIO.netObj

Class NetClass

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.xuset.objectIO.netObj.AbstractNetObject
      • net.xuset.objectIO.netObj.NetClass
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    NetObject
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ArrayNetClass, DummyNetClass, HashNetClass

    public abstract class NetClass
extends AbstractNetObject
    NetClass is used to store and organize NetObject instances. The updates of the stored NetObject instances are combined into one MarkupMsg object when the serialization occurs. Deserializing takes the single message and splits it up. The split-up messages are then distributed to the correct NetObject instances.

    To determine which NetObject a message belongs to, the id of the NetObject is used. When serializing a NetObject within a NetClass, the NetClass adds the NetObjects id into the message. So when it comes time to deserialize, the NetClass finds the NetObject with the same id as the one with message. If no NetObject is found, the message is silently discarded.

    NetClass is abstract so that the implementations can decide on how to store, remove, and retrieve NetObjects.

    Since:
    1.0

    • Method Detail

      • addObj

        public abstract void addObj(NetObject obj)
        Adds an object to the NetClass. The given object can now be serialized and deserialized through the NetClass.
        Parameters:
        obj - the object to store in the NetClass

      • removeObj

        public abstract boolean removeObj(NetObject obj)
        Removes the given object from the NetClass. Attempts to serialize and deserialize through the NetClass for the given object will fail.
        Parameters:
        obj - the object to remove
        Returns:
        true if the object was found and removed

      • iterator

        protected abstract java.util.Iterator<NetObject> iterator()
        Protected method that gets an iterator that can be used to access every NetObject stored by this NetClass
        Returns:
        the iterator for the NetClass

      • getObj

        protected NetObject getObj(java.lang.String id)
        Searches the stored NetObjects for the one with the same id as the given id.
        Parameters:
        id - the id of the NetObject to return
        Returns:
        the NetObject whose id equals the given id or null if no NetObject could be found

      • serializeToMsg

        public MarkupMsg serializeToMsg()
        Description copied from interface: NetObject
        Converts the entire object into a MarkupMsg object. The entire object's state should be stored inside the returned MarkupMsg object. When the MarkupMsg object gets deserialized, the new state of the object should be identical to when it was serialized.
        Returns:
        a MarkupMsg object with the entire state of the NetObject stored.

      • hasUpdates

        public boolean hasUpdates()
        Description copied from interface: NetObject
        Indicates if the objects state has changed since the last call to serializeUpdates().
        Returns:
        true if the object has changed and can be updated.

      • serializeUpdates

        public MarkupMsg serializeUpdates()
        Description copied from interface: NetObject
        This method only serializes the state that has changed since the last call to this method. serializeToMsg() converts the entire state into a MarkupMsg object but this method converts only what has changed since the last call. This method is significantly more bandwidth friendly than serializeToMsg(). If the object has not changed since the last call, an empty MarkupMsg object is returned.
        Returns:
        the updated and partial state of the object as a MarkupMsg object

      • deserializeMsg

        public void deserializeMsg(MarkupMsg msg)
        Description copied from interface: NetObject
        Deserialize the given MarkupMsg object. The entire state of the NetObject does not have to be present in the given MarkupMsg object for this method to work correctly. It can take a partial or complete state and update itself accordingly.
